case_name: Pursa Ltd. v. Union of India

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 33 of 1953 was filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 33 of 1953. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 16th May, 1951, of the High

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated 16th May 1951 of Patna High Court in Miscellaneous Judicial Case No. 126 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 33 of 1953. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 16th May, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature at Patna in Miscellaneous Judicial Case No. 126 of 1950, arising out

facts.text: Arising out of Order dated 17th May 1949 of Income-tax Appellate Tribunal Calcutta in I.T.A. No. 147 of 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 16th May, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature at Patna in Miscellaneous Judicial Case No. 126 of 1950, arising out of the Order dated the 17th May, 1949, of the Income-tax App

facts.text: Assessment for Pursa Ltd. for assessment year 1945-46, accounting period 1st October 1943 to 30th September 1944.

anchor.surface_text: The controvery arose in course of the proceedings for the assessment of Pursa Ltd. to income-tax for the assessment year 1945-46, the relevant accounting year covering the period between the 1st October, 1943, to 30th September, 1944.

facts.text: Pursa Ltd. incorporated in 1905 under Indian Companies Act, shareholders and directors residents in United Kingdom.

anchor.surface_text: Pursa Ltd., was a company incorporated in 1905 under the Indian Companies Act but all its shareholders and directors were residents in the United Kingdom.

facts.text: Business of Pursa Ltd.: growers of sugarcane, manufacturers of sugar and dealers in sugar.

anchor.surface_text: The business of the company was that of growers of sugarcane, manufacturers of sugar and dealers in sugar.

facts.text: Crushing season for manufacture of sugar is from December to April each year. Common ground.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the crushing season for the manufacture of sugar is from December to April of each year.

facts.text: Towards end of 1942, attempt made to sell entire business of company but failed.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that towards the end of 1942 an attempt was made to sell the entire business of the company but such attempt did not succeed.

facts.text: Middle of 1943, directors commenced negotiations for sale of factory and other assets with object of winding up company.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the case filed by the respondent in this appeal that in the middle of 1943 the directors of the company commenced negotiations for the sale of the factory and other assets of the company with the ultimate object of winding up

facts.text: On 9th August 1943, inventory prepared and firm offer received from Dalmia Jain Company Ltd. for purchase of factory and stores.

anchor.surface_text: From the correspondence, affidavit and other materials placed before the tribunal and referred to by Sarjoo Prasad J. in his judgment it appears that on the 9th August, 1943, an inventory was prepared and a firm offer was received from Dalmia

facts.text: On 16th August 1943, offer communicated by cable to directors in England.

anchor.surface_text: This offer was on the 16th August, 1943, communicated by cable to the directors in England.

facts.text: On 20th August 1943, directors asked local managers to proceed with matter anticipating shareholders sanction.

anchor.surface_text: On the 20th August, 1943, the directors, asked the local managers in India to proceed with the matter in anticipation of the sanction of the shareholders which the directors expected to obtain at an extraordinary general meeting to be held very

facts.text: Extraordinary general meeting held on 8th October 1943, firm offer accepted, concluded agreement for sale.

anchor.surface_text: That meeting, however, was held on the 8th October, 1943, i.e., 8 days after the accounting year had started., At that meeting the firm offer of Dalmia Jain Company Ltd. was accepted and a concluded agreement for sale came into existence.

facts.text: On 7th December 1943, written memorandum of agreement executed to sell assets to Dalmia Jain for Rs 28 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: On the 7th December, 1943, a written memorandum of agreement was executed whereby the company agreed to sell and demise to Dalmia Jain Company Ltd., free from all mortgages and charges at and for the price of rupees twenty-eight lacs all the lan

facts.text: Assets as on 9th August 1943, subject to subsequent use and consumption, excluding sugar and grain stocks on that date and stores after.

anchor.surface_text: ds, buildings, machinery and plant and all vats, reservoirs, cisterns, pumps, machinery, engines, boilers, plant, implements, utensils, tramways, furniture, stores, articles and things as on the ninth day of August, one thousand nine hundred and for

facts.text: Dalmia Jain paid Rs 28 lacs on 7 Dec 1943, possession on 10 Dec 1943.

anchor.surface_text: Dalmia Jain Company Ltd., paid the sum of rupees twenty-eight lacs on the same day and on the 10th December, 1943, they got possession of the factory.

facts.text: On date of sale, company possessed sugar stock valued at Rs six lacs, excluded from sale, continued to sell up to June 1944.

anchor.surface_text: On the date of the aforesaid sale, the company possessed sugar stock valued at rupees six lacs which was excluded from the sale. This stock of sugar the company continued to sell up to June, 1944.

facts.text: Between 9 Aug 1943 and 10 Dec 1943, machinery and plant never used except keeping in trim; throughout accounting period not used.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, not disputed that between the 9th August, 1943, when the firm offer was obtained and the 10th December, 1943, when possession of the factory was made over to Dalmia Jain Company Ltd., the company never used the machinery and plan

facts.text: Company went into voluntary liquidation on 20th June 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The company went into voluntary liquidation on the 20th June, 1945.

facts.text: Surplus of Rs. 13,05,144 arising out of sale of plant and machinery.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal referred the following two questions for the opinion of the High Court On the facts and in the circumstances of this case is the surplus of Rs. 13,05,144 arising out of the sale of the plant and machinery of the sugar factory charge

facts.text: Profit of Rs. 15,882 on sale of stores.

anchor.surface_text: Was the profit of Rs. 15,882 on the sale of stores of the factory taxable under the Income-tax Act in the circumstances of this case ?

facts.text: Patna High Court Division Bench: Shearer J and Sarjoo Prasad JJ delivered separate judgments on 27th February 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The reference came up for hearing before a Division Bench consisting of Shearer and Sarjoo Prasad JJ. and after a prolonged hearing the learned Judges delivered separate judgments on the27th February. 1951, giving divergent answers to the quest

facts.text: Ramaswami J agreed with Sarjoo Prasad J on first question, Shearer J on second, on 16th May 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The matter thereupon was placed before a third Judge, Ramaswami J. who, after a fresh hearing delivered his judgment on the 16th May, 1951, agreeing with Sarjoo Prasad J. on the first question and with Shearer J. on the second question.

facts.text: High Court majority: first question affirmative (against assessee), second negative (favour assessee).

anchor.surface_text: The result was that the High Court by a majority decision answered the first question in the affirmative, i.e., against the assessee, and the second question in the negative, i,e. in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer order dated 21st June 1947 added Rs 13,05,144 to profits under s10(2)(vii).

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, however, by his order dated the 21st June, 1947, held that the profits of the sale of machinery and plant were liable to assessment under section 10 (2) (vii) of the Act and added a sum of Rs. 13,05,144 to the profits.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner dismissed appeal on 30th January 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax having dismissed the liquidators appeal on the 30th January, 1947,

facts.text: Tribunal dismissed appeal on 17th May 1949.

anchor.surface_text: the liquidators went up on further appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal. By its order dated the 17th May, 1949, the tribunal dismissed that appeal.

facts.text: Machinery and plant not used at all during the accounting year.

anchor.surface_text: it completely overlooked the fact which is plainly in evidence on the record that the machinery and plant which were sold had not at all been used for the purposes of the business carried on in the accounting year

facts.text: Company admitted carrying on business up to date of sale 7 Dec 1943.

facts.text: No sugar manufactured during the whole accounting year.

anchor.surface_text: It is nobody's case and it has not been found that the company had manufactured any sugar during the whole of the accounting year.

issues.text: Whether the assessee was carrying on business during the accounting year such that profits from sale of plant and machinery are taxable under section 10?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Machinery and plant sold had not been used at all for business purposes during the accounting year, so proviso deeming excess as profits does not apply

holdings.text: The machinery or plant referred to in clause vii must be the same as those mentioned in the earlier clauses, i.e., such machinery or plant as were used for the purposes of the business, profession or vocation

anchor.surface_text: the machinery or plant referred to in clause  vii  must be the same as those mentioned in the earlier clauses, i.e., such machinery or plant as were used for the purposes of the business, profession or vocation. Indeed, the position has been made clear and placed beyond any doubt by the subsequent amendment of 1946 which added the word such in clause  vii .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of sub-section (2) links clause (vii) to prior clauses requiring use for business; confirmed by 1946 amendment adding 'such'

holdings.text: The words 'used for the purposes of the business' obviously mean used for the purpose of enabling the owner to carry on the business and earn profits in the business

anchor.surface_text: The words used for the purposes of the business obviously mean used for the purpose of enabling the owner to carry on the business and earn profits in the business. In other words, the machinery or plant must be used for the purpose of that business which is actually carried on and the profits of which are assessable under section 10  1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Phrase requires actual connection to business operations yielding taxable profits under s.10(1)

holdings.text: In order to attract the operation of clauses v, vi and vii the machinery and plant must be such as were used, in whatever sense that word is taken, at least for a part of the accounting year

anchor.surface_text: The word used has been read in some of the cases in a wide sense so as to include a passive as well as active user. It is not necessary, for the purposes of the present appeal, to express any opinion on that point on which the High Courts have expressed different views. It is, however, clear that in order to attract the operation clauses  v ,  vi  and  vii  the machinery and plant must be such as were used, in whatever sense that word is taken, at least for a part of the accounting year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Used' requires some employment (active or passive) during accounting period for allowances and proviso

holdings.text: If the machinery and plant have not at all been used at any time during the accounting year no allowance can be claimed under clause vii in respect them and the second proviso also does not come into operation

anchor.surface_text: If the machinery and plant have not at all been used at any time during the accounting year no allowance can be claimed under clause  vii  in respect them and the second proviso also does not come into operation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No prior allowance possible without use, hence no balancing charge via proviso

holdings.text: The tribunal misdirected itself in law as to the meaning and import of the relevant provisions of section 10 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Although the High Court will not disturb or go behind the finding of fact of the tribunal, it is not well settled that where it is competent for a tribunal to make findings in fact which are excluded from review, the appeal court has always jurisdiction to intervene if it appears either that the tribunal has misunderstood the statutory language--because the proper construction of the statutory language is a matter of law--or that the tribunal has made a finding for which there is no evidence or which is inconsistent with the evidence and contradictory of it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal overlooked non-use of machinery and misconstrued s.10(2)(vii)

holdings.text: Where it is competent for a tribunal to make findings in fact which are excluded from review, the appeal court has always jurisdiction to intervene if it appears either that the tribunal has misunderstood the statutory language or that the tribunal has made a finding for which there is no evidence or which is inconsistent with the evidence

anchor.surface_text: See Lord Normand in Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Fraser. It appears to us that the tribunal misdirected itself in law as to the meaning and import of the relevant provisions of section 10 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction exists for legal misdirection or evidentiary flaws, per Fraser precedent

holdings.text: If the sale of the machinery was a part of the applicant company's carrying on of the business then the sale must be regarded as an ordinary operation of such business and consequently the profits arising out of such ordinary business operation would be assessable under the provisions of section 10(1) and it would not be necessary to have recourse to the statutory fiction

anchor.surface_text: If, as held by the tribunal, the sale of the machinery was a part of the applicant company's carrying on of the business then the sale must be regarded as an ordinary operation of such business and consequently the profits arising out of such ordinary business operation would be assessable under the provisions of section 10  1  and it would not be necessary to have recourse to the statutory fiction created by the second proviso to clause  vii  under which the excess of the sale proceeds over the written down value is to be deemed to be profits of the business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's view creates inconsistency: ordinary sale taxable under s10(1) without deeming; proviso for non-ordinary requires prior use

precedents.citation: Shaw Wallace Co.s case 1 L. R, 59 I.A. 206 at p. 213

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by the Judicial Committee in Shaw Wallace Co.s case 1 the fundamental idea underlying each of these words is the companytinuous exercise of an activity and the same central idea is implicit in the words carried on by him occurring in section 10 1 and those critical words are an essential companystituent of that which is to produce the taxable income. Therefore, it is clear that the tax is payable only in respect of the profits or gains of the business which is carried on by the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: the machinery or plant referred to in clause  vii  must be the same as those mentioned in the earlier clauses, i.e., such machinery or plant as were used for the purposes of the business, profession or vocation. Indeed, the position has been made clear and placed beyond any doubt by the subsequent amendment of 1946 which added the word such in clause  vii .

anchor.surface_text: The words used for the purposes of the business obviously mean used for the purpose of enabling the owner to carry on the business and earn profits in the business. anchor.surface_text: The word used has been read in some of the cases in a wide sense so as to include a passive as well as active user. It is not necessary, for the purposes of the present appeal, to express any opinion on that point on which the High Courts have expressed different views. It is, however, clear that in order to attract the operation clauses  v ,  vi  and  vii  the machinery and plant must be such as were used, in whatever sense that word is taken, at least for a part of the accounting year.

It appears to us that the tribunal misdirected itself in law as to the meaning and import of the relevant provisions of section 10 of the Act. t companypletely overlooked the fact which is plainly in evidence on the record that the machinery and plant which were sold had number at all been used for the purposes of the business carried on in the accounting year and companysequently the second proviso to section 10  2   vii  companyld have numberapplication to the sale proceeds of such machinery and plant. In fact the entire decision of the tribunal was vitiated by its failure to keep in view the true meaning and scope of section 10  2   vii  and cannot, therefore, be supported.

anchor.surface_text: Although the High Court will not disturb or go behind the finding of fact of the tribunal, it is not well settled that where it is competent for a tribunal to make findings in fact which are excluded from review, the appeal court has always jurisdiction to intervene if it appears either that the tribunal has misunderstood the statutory language--because the proper construction of the statutory language is a matter of law--or that the tribunal has made a finding for which there is no evidence or which is inconsistent with the evidence and contradictory of it.

It appears to us that the tribunal misdirected itself in law as to the meaning and import of the relevant provisions of section 10 of the Act. t companypletely overlooked the fact which is plainly in evidence on the record that the machinery and plant which were sold had number at all been used for the purposes of the business carried on in the accounting year and companysequently the second proviso to section 10  2   vii  companyld have numberapplication to the sale proceeds of such machinery and plant. In fact the entire decision of the tribunal was vitiated by its failure to keep in view the true meaning and scope of section 10  2   vii  and cannot, therefore, be supported.

edges.explanation: The holding sets out the condition (sale as part of carrying on business) for treating profits as taxable business income under section 10, addressing the issue.

anchor.surface_text: If, as held by the tribunal, the sale of the machinery was a part of the applicant company's carrying on of the business then the sale must be regarded as an ordinary operation of such business and consequently the profits arising out of such ordinary business operation would be assessable under the provisions of section 10  1  and it would not be necessary to have recourse to the statutory fiction created by the second proviso to clause  vii  under which the excess of the sale proceeds over the written down value is to be deemed to be profits of the business.

It appears to us that the tribunal misdirected itself in law as to the meaning and import of the relevant provisions of section 10 of the Act. t companypletely overlooked the fact which is plainly in evidence on the record that the machinery and plant which were sold had number at all been used for the purposes of the business carried on in the accounting year and companysequently the second proviso to section 10  2   vii  companyld have numberapplication to the sale proceeds of such machinery and plant. In fact the entire decision of the tribunal was vitiated by its failure to keep in view the true meaning and scope of section 10  2   vii  and cannot, therefore, be supported.
